passage_text: • minimum points: (p i + 2 k pi, -1) , where k is an integer. • symmetry: since cos(- x) = cos (x) then cos (x) is an even functionand its graph is symmetric with respect to the y axis. • intervals of increase/decrease: over one period and from 0 to 2pi,cos (x) is decreasing on (0, pi) increasing on (p i, 2pi). • symmetry: since cot(-x) = - cot(x) then cot (x) is an odd function andits graph is symmetric with respect the origin. • intervals of increase/decrease: over one period and from 0 to pi,cot (x) is decreasing.

• intervals of increase/decrease: over one period and from 0 to 2pi,sin (x) is increasing on the intervals (0, pi/2) and (3 pi/2, 2pi), anddecreasing on the interval (pi/2, 3pi/2). Cosecant Function: f(x) = csc (x) • Graph. • Domain: all real numbers except k pi, k is an integer. • symmetry: since cot(-x) = - cot(x) then cot (x) is an odd function andits graph is symmetric with respect the origin. • intervals of increase/decrease: over one period and from 0 to pi,cot (x) is decreasing.

1 Range: all real numbers. 2  Period = pi. 3  x intercepts: x = pi /2 + k pi, where k is an integer. 4  symmetry: since cot(-x) = - cot(x) then cot (x) is an odd function and its graph is symmetric with respect the origin. 5  intervals of increase/decrease: over one period and from 0 to pi, cot (x) is decreasing. The properties of the 6 trigonometric functions: sin (x) , cos (x) , tan(x) , cot (x) , sec (x) and csc (x) are discussed. These include the graph, domain, range, asymptotes (if any), symmetry, x and y intercepts and maximum and minimum points.

The function is decreasing on the x-interval (3,5) . The function is constant on the x-interval (-2,1) . This is open interval notation. Differing notations for increasing intervals: Regarding intervals of increasing or decreasing on a graph, it is a popular convention to use only open interval notation.

1 symmetry: since sin(-x) = - sin (x) then sin (x) is an odd function and its graph is symmetric with respect to the origin (0, 0). 2  intervals of increase/decrease: over one period and from 0 to 2pi, sin (x) is increasing on the intervals (0, pi/2) and (3pi/2, 2pi), and decreasing on the interval (pi/2, 3pi/2). The properties of the 6 trigonometric functions: sin (x) , cos (x) , tan(x) , cot (x) , sec (x) and csc (x) are discussed. These include the graph, domain, range, asymptotes (if any), symmetry, x and y intercepts and maximum and minimum points.

Let's first draw graph on the interval `[0,pi]` . Find some values of function: 1  if `x=0` then `y=sin(0)=0` ; 2  if `x=pi/6` then `y=sin(pi/6)=1/2` ; 3  if `x=pi/2` then `y=sin(pi/2)=1` ; 4  if `x=pi` then `y=sin(pi)=0` . Since `y=sin(x)` is odd, then draw part of the graph symmetric about origin to the graph on interval `[0,pi]` . We've obtained graph of the function on interval `[-pi,pi]` . Now, using the fact that sine is periodic with period `2pi` we can draw graph of the function on all domain.

So since the interval we're looking at is y = sin x, x = -pi/2. . pi/2: At-pi/2, sin x is -1 (since 3pi/2 - 2pi = -pi/2) and at pi/2, sin x = 1. At 0, sin x = 0. So start from (-pi/2, -1), draw the right half of a concave-up curve up to (0,0), then the left half of a concave-down curve up to (pi/2, 1).

We've obtained graph of the functon on interval `[0,pi]` . Since `y=sin(x)` is odd, then draw part of the graph symmetric about origin to the graph on interval `[0,pi]` . We've obtained graph of the function on interval `[-pi,pi]` . Now, using the fact that sine is periodic with period `2pi` we can draw graph of the function on all domain.

The derivative of f(x) at the point x is equal to the slope of the tangent to y = f(x) at x. The derivative of f(x) at the point x is equal to the slope of the tangent to y = f(x) at x. The graph of a function y = f (x) in an interval is increasing (or rising) if all of its tangents have positive slopes. That is, it is increasing if as x increases, y also increases. The graph of a function y = f (x) in an interval is decreasing (or falling) if all of its tangents have negative slopes. That is, it is decreasing if as x increases, y decreases.

And, a function is known as decreasing if y-value decreases when x is increases and denoted as if x 1 2 $\Rightarrow$ f(x 1 2). A function that either increases or decreases everywhere in an Interval is called monotonic on the Interval. When the function is increasing, the graph of the function rises from left to right. On the other hand, while the function is decreasing, its graph falls from left to right. The function y = x 2 is decreasing in the interval (-$\infty$,0) and is increasing in the interval (0, $\infty$).
